question: Question_08_(b)
statement:
True or false (explain your answer): Let $T$ be the transformation of
$\mathbb{R}^2\rightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$ given by
$T\begin{pmatrix} x\\ y \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} x+y\\ x-y \end{pmatrix}$.
Then $T$ is a linear transformation.
sols:
The linear transformation will have the properties, such that
$T(cv)=cT(v)$ and $T(v_1+v_2)=T(v_1)+T(v_2)$. We check these properties

$T(c\begin{pmatrix} x\\ y \end{pmatrix})=T\begin{pmatrix} cx\\ cy \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} cx+cy\\ cx-cy \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} c(x+y)\\ c(x-y) \end{pmatrix}=c\begin{pmatrix} x+y\\ x-y \end{pmatrix}=cT\begin{pmatrix} x\\ y \end{pmatrix}$,

\begin{align*}
T(\begin{pmatrix} x_1\\ y_1 \end{pmatrix}+\begin{pmatrix} x_2\\ y_2 \end{pmatrix})&=
T\begin{pmatrix} x_1+x_2\\ y_1+y_2 \end{pmatrix}\\
&=\begin{pmatrix} x_1+x_2+y_1+y_2\\ x_1+x_2-y_1-y_2 \end{pmatrix}\\
&= \begin{pmatrix} x_1+y_1\\ x_1-y_1 \end{pmatrix}+\begin{pmatrix} x_2+y_2\\ x_2-y_2 \end{pmatrix}\\
&= T\begin{pmatrix} x_1\\ y_1 \end{pmatrix}+T\begin{pmatrix} x_2\\ y_2 \end{pmatrix}.
\end{align*}

Therefore, $T$ is a linear transformation.
